nodes.text: Applying statistical physics to monetary economics: conservation of money and entropy principles explain emergent money and income distributions and illuminate monetary dynamics
Money is conserved in pairwise transactions among ordinary agents (local conservation law of money balances)
Use kinetic theory: Boltzmann kinetic equation with detailed balance and its Fokker-Planck limit to model evolution of money distribution P(m,t)
Stationary solution for additive, time-reversal symmetric transactions is the exponential (Boltzmann-Gibbs) money distribution P(m) proportional to exp(-m/Tm), implying strong inequality
If microscopic transaction rules break time-reversal symmetry (e.g., multiplicative percentage transfers), stationary distributions are non-exponential (Gamma-like or power-law tails)
Fokker-Planck reduction: for small additive transfers, drift A and diffusion B give stationary temperature Tm = B/A and exponential P(m)
Empirical evidence from income data: lower class incomes follow exponential distribution, upper tail follows Pareto power law, yielding a two-class structure
Maximum entropy principle: entropy S increases under kinetic evolution and is maximized by the exponential distribution subject to conserved total money

Money is a digital accounting layer distinct from the physical layer; conservation of money is a prerequisite for preventing free riding and for money to function as medium, measure, and store of value
Boundary conditions (e.g., lower bound m>0 or credit limits) are essential for achieving a stationary distribution; without bounds allowing negative balances, no equilibrium is reached
Agent-based simulations show initial equal money allocations evolve to broad, then exponential stationary distributions when lower bound m>0 is imposed

Income inequality spikes (fraction of income to upper class) correlate with market bubbles and with central bank quantitative easing; empirical IRS data show QE coincided with increased upper-tail income share

Conclusion: exogenous money injection by the state or central bank (vertical transactions) is the ultimate source of net monetary profits and contributes to increased inequality and enables capitalist profit cycles

Debt is distinct from money: borrowing creates debt obligations (particle-antiparticle analogy) that remove boundary constraints and destabilize the monetary ensemble unless debt limits or enforcement exist

Banks aggregate lending, creating debt liabilities for borrowers and assets for banks; this amplifies and anonymizes debt (so-called money creation), reserve requirements are soft constraints, and bank-created debt can trigger systemic crises requiring central bank monetization
Limitation and conceptual warning: models that conflate money with wealth or integrate out money cannot capture monetary crises and misrepresent conservation and nonconservation mechanisms
